channel.title: Java, AP Computer Sciences class

item.title: Java, AP Computer Sciences class
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:11, topic:238083”][quote author=Ollie link=topic=314309.msg2511254#msg2511254 date=1225303505]

public static void main(String[] args) {
  double angle, distance, velocity, target; //declare my variables here
    System.out.println("Enter Distance to Target: "); //ask the user for the distance to the target
    distance = (Math.pow(velocity, 2)) * Math.sin(angle * 2) / 32.2; //using the formula, calculate the distance
    double percentage = (distance > target ? ((distance - target) / distance)*100 : ((target - distance) / target)*100); //calculate the percentage
    if(percentage < 0.1) //conditional branch to check the percentage is less than 0.1
      System.out.println("You Hit!"); //congratulate the user
     System.out.println("You Missed by " + Math.abs(target - distance) + "m!"); //tell the user that they have missed, then by how much

[/quote]

Those lines are useless comments and should NOT be commented. Overcommenting is as bad as not commenting at all.[/quote]

oh no i agree, i was doing it to work out steps in my head at time, that was a release i did after just making it, and discovering it. i debugged everything to fine it, then when i got it didnt bother to tidy up! just posted it!

but yes Mopman, big respect

Read full topic

item.title: Java, AP Computer Sciences class
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:3, topic:238083”] public static void main(String[] args) { double angle, distance, velocity, target; //declare my variables here System.out.println("Enter Distance to Target: "); //ask the user for the distance to the target distance = (Math.pow(velocity, 2)) * Math.sin(angle * 2) / 32.2; //using the formula, calculate the distance double percentage = (distance > target ? ((distance - target) / distance)*100 : ((target - distance) / target)*100); //calculate the percentage if(percentage < 0.1) //conditional branch to check the percentage is less than 0.1 System.out.println("You Hit!"); //congratulate the user System.out.println("You Missed by " + Math.abs(target - distance) + "m!"); //tell the user that they have missed, then by how much [/quote]

Those lines are useless comments and should NOT be commented. Overcommenting is as bad as not commenting at all.

item.title: Java, AP Computer Sciences class
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

use object orientation

PLAN your program, put on code documentation. its there to help you

[code]
public static void main(String[] args) {
double angle, distance, velocity, target; //declare my variables here
for(int tries = 0; tries < 5; tries++) {
System.out.println("Enter Distance to Target: "); //ask the user for the distance to the target
target = Keyboard.readDouble(); //request input using the csl.Keyboard class defined in my imports
System.out.println("Enter Angle: ");
angle = Keyboard.readDouble();
System.out.println("Enter Velocity: ");
velocity = Keyboard.readDouble();

angle *= (3.14159265 / 180.0); //convert the angle into radians
distance = (Math.pow(velocity, 2)) * Math.sin(angle * 2) / 32.2; //using the formula, calculate the distance

double percentage = (distance > target ? ((distance - target) / distance)*100 : ((target - distance) / target)*100); //calculate the percentage
if(percentage < 0.1) //conditional branch to check the percentage is less than 0.1
  System.out.println("You Hit!"); //congratulate the user

else
System.out.println("You Missed by " + Math.abs(target - distance) + “m!”); //tell the user that they have missed, then by how much

} //end for(int tries = 0; tries < 5; tries++)
} //end main[/code]

or something like that anyway, i havent tested it, i coded it on the quick reply box

Read full topic

item.title: Java, AP Computer Sciences class
item.dc:creator: @Swift Swift
item.description:
@Swift wrote:

I’m so confused about this. Here’s what they expect me to do:

The Missile Game 
        The distance to the landing point of a projectile, launched at an angle x (in radians) with an initial velocity of v ( in feet per second ), ignoring air resistance, is given by the formula :

Distance = v2 * sin (2*x) / 32.2

     Write a program that implements a game in which the user first enters the distance to a target. The user then enters the angle and velocity for launching the projectile. If the projectile comes within one tenth of one percent of the distance to the target, the target is blown up and the user wins the game. If the projectile doesn't come close enough, the user is told how far off the projectile is, and is allowed to try again ( don't enter a new distance though ). If after five  tries there isn't a winning input, then the user loses the game.


     To simplify input for the user, your program should allow the angle to be input in  degrees, however the sin function only allows for a radian measure  parameter. The conversion from degrees to radians is:

Radians = Degrees * 3.14159265 /180.0

     You will need to use methods from the Math class, and I would like a  boolean variable used that determines whether the target was hit or not. Your program should properly prompt the user for input and label output values. It should be well documented as well.</blockquote>

Here’s what I have so far, lol don’t laugh:

[code]//|*********************************|
//|Matt Gates - Period 11 |
//| |
//|*********************************|
import cs1.Keyboard;

public class missle
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{

int tries = 0;
double d, a, v, Radians, Degrees, target;


System.out.println ("The Missle Game");

while(tries <= 5){		
System.out.print ("Enter target distance: ");
target = Keyboard.readDouble();		
	
System.out.print ("Enter angle: ");
a = Keyboard.readDouble();

System.out.print ("Enter velocity: ");
v = Keyboard.readDouble();

Radians = a * 3.14159265 /180.0;

d = (v*2) * (Math.sin((a*2) / 32.2));
if(d < (0.001 * target)){
System.out.println ("You hit!");
tries++;}

if(d > )){
	System.out.println ("You hit!");
	tries++;}	

if(d == target)
	System.out.println ("You hit!");
}

}

}[/code]

??

Read full topic
